Award.AwardTitle: Houston Summer School on Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the 2015 Houston Summer School on Dynamical Systems, taking place May 20-28, 2015 at the University of Houston. This event introduces graduate students to recent progress and novel techniques in probabilistic dynamics and ergodic theory, as well as giving a bird's-eye view of fundamental areas of dynamics. The school also covers applications to other areas where these ideas are useful, such as mathematical neuroscience, statistical mechanics, and information theory.

The core of the school consists of four lecture series covering topics in uniform hyperbolicity; partial hyperbolicity; parabolic dynamics and renormalization; and decay of correlations via spectral gap, coupling, and cones. These lectures will be given by internationally recognized researchers in dynamical systems: Boris Hasselblatt (Tufts University); Keith Burns (Northwestern University); Jayadev Athreya (UIUC); Vaughn Climenhaga (Houston); Matt Nicol (Houston); Will Ott (Houston); Andrew Torok (Houston). The school also includes further lectures on advanced topics and applications, informal review sessions, problem sessions, and project sessions, with particular emphasis on maximizing interactions between students and lecturers and allowing plenty of opportunity for discussion.

Summer school web site: www.math.uh.edu/~climenha/2015-school.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "2015 Houston Summer School in Dynamical Systems" was held from May 20-28, 2015 at the University of Houston. Participants included 55 graduate students, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 postdoctoral fellow.

 

The school consisted of four short courses covering various aspects of dynamical systems theory, with an emphasis on the difference between systems with hyperbolic behavior and those with parabolic or elliptic behavior; in particular, how these deterministic systems display different degrees of randomness. These questions are well studied in the scientific literature, but many of the key ideas are not readily available in the literature in a form that is accessible to graduate students; this was one motivation for the school.

 

Lectures were given by four professors at University of Houston (the four co-PIs of this grant) as well as Boris Hasselblatt (Tufts University), Keith Burns (Northwestern), and Jon Chaika (Utah). As part of the school, the participants completed short projects that involved reading and reporting on a paper from the research literature.

 

In a survey given at the end of the school, student feedback was very positive, with 98% of respondents indicating that they would recommend the summer school to other students interested in dynamical systems. A similar event was run in May 2016, for which videos of the lectures are available at https://www.math.uh.edu/dynamics/school/index2016.php -- the organizers are planning another such event in May 2017.
